Title: 10+ Guidelines for Better Tables in R
Description: This blog post takes table-making guidelines laid out by data visualization expert Jon Schwabish and shows how they can be achieved using the gt package.

Title: A Scientist's Guide to R: Step 2.3 - string manipulation and regex
Description: Covers some of the core functions of the stringr package and has a section on regular expressions for pattern matching.

Title: A Twitter bot with {rtweet} and GitHub Actions
Description: This blog post walks through the process of creating a Twitter bot that posts satellite images of London using the rtweet package and GitHub Actions.

Title: broom
Description: The broom packages enables you to take output from statistical models and convert it into tidy tibbles. Practically speaking, this means you can easily access elements of the output (e.g. pull out p-values to include in text in an RMarkdown document).

Title: cowplot
Description: The cowplot package provides various features that help with creating publication-quality figures, such as a set of themes, functions to align plots and arrange them into complex compound figures, and functions that make it easy to annotate plots and or mix plots with images.

Title: Data Cleaning Flipbook
Description: This flipbook walks through several examples of messy data and shows how to clean them with R.

Title: Data Visualization: A Practical Introduction
Description: This book demonstrates how to create high-quality data visualization in R. Complete with code samples, it's a great resource to improve your visualizations.

Title: Data wrangling for spatial analysis: R Workshop
Description: Materials from a 2020 workshop on spatial analysis in R.

Title: Deep dive intro dplyr
Description: This tutorial is for anyone interested in learning the basics of the dplyr package. We'll be focusing on data exploration and manipulation, building off of the examples in the dplyr package documentation using the Palmer Penguins dataset.

Title: dplyr
Description: dplyr is a grammar of data manipulation, providing a consistent set of verbs that help you solve the most common data manipulation challenges. It is one of the core tidyverse packges.

Title: Drawing Anything with ggplot2
Description: This two-part workshop is a deep dive on what you can do with ggplot2.

Title: forcats
Description: R uses factors to handle categorical variables, variables that have a fixed and known set of possible values. Factors are also helpful for reordering character vectors to improve display. The goal of the forcats package is to provide a suite of tools that solve common problems with factors, including changing the order of levels or the values. Some examples include:

Title: Functions and Themes for gt tables
Description: This blog post shows how to make nice tables using the gt package.

Title: Geocomputation with R
Description: Geocomputation with R is "a book on geographic data analysis, visualization and modeling." An in-depth yet approachable book, it is a great place to start (and a great reference) for those looking to learn about making maps in R.

Title: geofacet
Description: geofacet enables you to make small multiple plots laid out in grids that are designed to represent the shapes of geographic areas (e.g. states in the United States).

Title: geogrid
Description: The geogrid packages enables you to "turn geospatial polygons like states, counties or local authorities into regular or hexagonal grids automatically."

Title: ggittext
Description: This package helps you fit text added to plots within boxes.

Title: ggspatial
Description: ggspatial provides additional functionality to maps created with ggplot2. For example, it has a function to add a scalebar to help users measure distances in maps.

Title: ggtext
Description: The ggtext package allows you to style text elements of plots. You can use it to add multiple colors to titles, subtitles, captions, etc.

Title: gt
Description: The gt package aims to create a grammar of tables (similar to the grammar of graphics that underlies ggplot2) and use this to help users create attractive tables that communicate effectively.
Related Resource: Functions and Themes for gt tables,10+ Guidelines for Better Tables in R

Title: gt Workshop 2020!
Description: Materials from a 2020 workshop about the gt R package.

Title: haven
Description: haven enables R to read and write various data formats used by other statistical packages, including SPSS, SAS, Stata, and more.

Title: Interactive web-based data visualization with R, plotly, and shiny
Description: This book provides an overview of the plotly package and has chapters that lay out how to make a wide range of graphs using it.

Title: jsonlite
Description: jsonlite is a package designed to make it easier to work with JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) data. This type of data is common when working with APIs (application programming interfaces).

Title: leaflet
Description: The leaflet package provides an interface to the popular javascript library of the same name that enables you to make interactive maps.

Title: lubridate
Description: lubridate is a tidyverse-friendly package to simplify the process of working with dates and times.
Related Resource: "R for Data Science, Chapter 16: Dates and Times"

Title: mapdeck
Description: mapdeck is a package for making interactive maps.

Title: Mapping ggplot geoms and aesthetic properties
Description: In ggplot, each geom uses certain aesthetic properties. This blog post is a cheatsheet to help you remember which geoms work with which aesthetic properties.

Title: patchwork
Description: The patchwork package enables you to combine multiple plots into a single graphic.

Title: plotly
Description: The plotly package enables you to make interactive visualizations. You can either generate figures in ggplot and then add interactivity or use other functions from the package to make interactive figures directly.
Related Resource: "Interactive web-based data visualization with R, plotly, and shiny"

Title: purrr
Description: The purrr package is focused on iteration. You can use it to do things like read in multiple sheets from an Excel spreadsheet into a single data frame, knit an RMarkdown to multiple reports, etc.

Title: R for Data Science
Description: Considered the "bible" of the tidyverse approach, this book has chapters on all of the fundamental skills you need to work with R.

Title: R for Data Science, Chapter 11: Data Import
Description: This chapter of R for Data Science teaches you how to import CSV and other rectangular data into R.

Title: R for Data Science, Chapter 16: Dates and Times
Description: This chapter of R for Data Science shows how to work with dates and times in R using the lubridate package.

Title: R Graph Gallery
Description: This website is a collection of visualization types, complete with R code that shows how to make them.

Title: R Graphics Cookbook
Description: This book has recipes that show how to do a variety of tasks in ggplot.

Title: readr
Description: readr is a package designed "to provide a fast and friendly way to read rectangular data (like csv, tsv, and fwf)."
Related Resource: "R for Data Science, Chapter 11: Data Import"

Title: readxl
Description: The readxl package simplifies the process of importing Excel files into R.

Title: RStudio Cloud Primers: Visualize Data
Description: These primers explain the basics of visualizing data in R.

Title: rtweet
Description: rtweet lets you access data from Twitter in order to analyze it in R.

Title: rvest
Description: rvest helps you scrape information from web pages.

Title: sf
Description: The sf package provides tools for working with simple features geospatial data.

Title: snapbox
Description: Add static basemaps from mapbox to maps made with ggplot2.

Title: Spreadsheet workflows in R
Description: This blog post shows some equivalents between workflows in R and Excel.

Title: stringr
Description: "The stringr package provide a cohesive set of functions designed to make working with strings as easy as possible."

Title: stringr.plus
Description: This package provides a few additional functions to supplement those in the string package. They include str_extract_before(), str_extract_after(), and others.

Title: Take A Sad Plot & Make It Better: A Case Study with R and ggplot2
Description: This presentation provides a case study of how to improve the quality of a plot.

Title: The ggplot flipbook
Description: This flipbook walks through plots created in ggplot step by step so you can learn how to make your own plots.

Title: The Glamour of Graphics
Description: This presentation at 2020 rstudio::conf shows how you can use ggplot to make high-quality visualizations.

Title: tidy data
Description: This Twitter thread explains the concept of tidy data with clear descriptions and illustrations.

Title: Tidy Data Vignette
Description: This article lays out the principles of tidy data and shows how you can use the tidyr package to get your data into this format.

Title: tidycensus
Description: The tidycensus package enables you to get data directly from the United States Census Bureau into R.

Title: tidyr
Description: The tidyr package is designed to help you get data into tidy format. With functions to go from wide data to long data, deal with missing values, and more, it provides a toolkit to ensure your data follows tidy principles.

Title: tidyverse
Description: The tidyverse is a collection of packages, all designed to work together. It is also an approach to coding that tends to be friendly to newcomers (but is powerful and used by experienced folks as well!).

Title: tigris
Description: "tigris is an R package that allows users to directly download and use TIGER/Line shapefiles from the US Census Bureau."

Title: tilemaps
Description: This package is designed to take a map and turn it into equally-spaced tile maps.

Title: tmap
Description: tmap is package designed to help you quickly make static and interactive maps.

Title: usethis
Description: usethis is very meta: it's an R package design to help you make your own R package.

Title: What is a tidyverse-centric approach?
Description: This blog post lays out what a tidyverse-centric approach to R is, and why you might consider using it in your own code.

Title: What is Takes to Tidy Census Data
Description: This walkthrough provides an example of cleaning Census data to demonstrate principles of tidy data.

Title: Working with categorical data in R without losing your mind
Description: Categorical data, called “factor” data in R, presents unique challenges in data wrangling. R users often look down at tools like Excel for automatically coercing variables to incorrect datatypes, but factor data in R can produce very similar issues. The stringsAsFactors=HELLNO movement and standard Tidyverse defaults have moved us away from the use of factors, but they are sometimes still necessary for analysis. This talk will outline common problems arising from categorical variable transformations in R, and show strategies to avoid them, using both base R and the Tidyverse (particularly, dplyr and forcats functions).

Title: Wrangling categorical data in R
Description: Data wrangling is a critical foundation of data science, and wrangling of categorical data is an important component of this process. However, categorical data can introduce unique issues in data wrangling, particularly in real-world settings with collaborators and periodically-updated dynamic data. This paper discusses common problems arising from categorical variable transformations in R, demonstrates the use of factors, and suggests approaches to address data wrangling challenges. For each problem, we present at least two strategies for management, one in base R and the other from the ‘tidyverse.’ We consider several motivating examples, suggest defensive coding strategies, and outline principles for data wrangling to help ensure data quality and sound analysis.

Title: zipcodeR
Description: zipcodeR is an R library that makes working with ZIP codes in R easier. It provides data on all U.S. ZIP codes using multiple open data sources, making it easier for social science researchers and data scientists to work with ZIP code-level data in projects.
